Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Hotfix]Disable DownloadCount Mapping temporarily" (#9150) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Temporarily disables mapping of the DownloadCount column to the Package and PackageRegistration entities.

After this has been merged, there will be a second PR reverting this as we only need this changeset to enable readonly scenarios while the DownloadCount column data type is being migrated.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Always show supported frameworks for packages" (#4598) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Today NuGet.org shows the frameworks only if there are dependencies in the packages.
Twitter thread: https://twitter.com/imperugo/status/899901309788225540

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet gallery UI should show target frameworks the package" (#4077) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Neither nuget.org nor preview.nuget.org show the target frameworks of a package. Consider a package that targets net40 and net45, but expresses no package dependencies. The gallery shows _no hint_ as to what projects the package might install into.

Even when dependencies are expressed, that's only a rough estimate, and can under express the compatibility of this package. For example, a package might take a dependency on NetStandard.Library when targeting netstandard1.5 but have no dependency for net40, and the gallery will only show netstandard1.5 on the page even though net40 is also a target. 

It seems like a super basic and critical trait of a package to be able to see on the gallery. Can it be added?

see also: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2805

### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Other/NA

### The Elevator Pitch

Allow optional package sources, i.e., sources that don't cause restore errors when missing. This would greatly improve local library development.

### Additional Context and Details

I regularly find myself working with multiple .NET libraries that reference each other as NuGet packages. When one of those libraries is in development, I often want to test it out in a dependent project on the same machine. Rather than updating the package references in the dependent project, I can just add a `NuGet.Config` to it with a `packageSource` for the local, work-in-progress library. That way, when I build the library, it generates a new .nupkg locally, which my dependent projects pick up with their custom package source.

Unfortunately, if somebody clones the dependent project repo and _not_ the library project, this causes NuGet restore to fail. The error is typically `Index was outside the bounds of the array` after displaying the config files in use, or  `error NU1301: The local source '...' doesn't exist.` This occurs whether I use `packageSources` or `fallbackFolderPackages` sections in my NuGet.Configs, and occurs for all NuGet clients (hence my selection above). It would be great to have some way of telling NuGet "use the package from this local source; if the source isn't there, just get it from the next source".

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "packages.lock.json conflict for two .csproj in same folder" (#11908) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
If I have two .csproj files in the same directory, that include different subsets of *.cs files, and I enable `RestorePackagesWithLockFile`, the resulting packages.lock.json files will conflict, overwriting each other.

There needs to be an easy way to rename one of the conflicting packages.lock.json files by setting an MSBuild property.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "packages.lock.json conflict for two .csproj in same folder" (#11908) at NuGet/Home

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: The ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button is still clickable after installing a package-the latest version with ‚ÄúPackages.config‚Äù format in PM UI PM UI " (#11907) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.3.0.104

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

Repro steps: 
1. Create a new Console App (.Net Framework) project.
2. Right-click the project and open Manage NuGet Packages in Solution Explorer.
3. Install a package-the latest version (e.g. Newtonsoft.Json 13.0.1) with ‚ÄúPackages.config‚Äù format into the project.
4. Observe the information of the package in the right panel.

Expected:
The ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button is non-clickable.

Actual:
The ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button is still clickable after installing a package-the latest version with ‚ÄúPackages.config‚Äù format in PM UI as below screenshot.
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/174979792-1d85128e-1585-45d6-b837-dd060fbd6770.png)

Note:
1. The issue does not repro on installing package-the latest version with ‚ÄúPackage Reference‚Äù format.
2. The issue does not repro on .Net Core template project.



### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: NuGet Server API reterns right link only for lowercase packages  " (#11897) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

NuGet V3 API

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

If the package name is **18.3.4-f-DTE-23727-0002** then the link will be formed like https://artifactory.***.***.com/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/page/18.3.4-f-dte-23727-0002/18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001.json
And as result, the link will not work as it's looking for package **18.3.4-f-dte-23727-0002**, not for **18.3.4-f-DTE-23727-0002** and response will be 
```
{
"count": 0,
"lower": "18.3.4-f-dte-23727-0002",
"parent": "https://artifactory.***.***.com/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/index.json",
"upper": "18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001",
"items": [],
"@id": "https://artifactory.dev.intapp.com/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/page/18.3.4-f-dte-23727-0002/18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001.json"
}
```
but must return result something like this: 
```
{
"count": 9,
"lower": "18.3.4-f-DTE-23727-0002",
"parent": "https://artifactory.***.***.com/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/index.json",
"upper": "18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001",
"items": [<9_ITEMS_HERE_TRUNCATED>],
"@id": "https://artifactory.***.***/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/page/18.3.4-f-DTE-23727-0002/18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001.json"
}
```
It does not work only if **lower** element has an upper case letter, for **upper** element it works anyway

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2022-30184 | .NET Information Disclosure Vulnerability" (#62) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2022-30184 | .NET Information Disclosure Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET 6.0 and .NET Core 3.1, NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version range from 3.5.0 to 6.2.0). This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A vulnerability exists in .NET 6.0, .NET Core 3.1, and NuGet clients (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version range from 3.5.0 to 6.2.0) where a nuget.org credential could be leaked. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/nuget/home/issues. (TBD) ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software ### NuGet & NuGet Packages - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 6.2.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 6.0.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.11.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.9.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.7.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.2.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 4.9.4 version or earlier. ### .NET SDK(s) - Any .NET 6.0 application running on .NET 6.0.5 or earlier. - Any .NET 3.1 application running on .NET Core 3.1.25 or earlier. ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a NuGet.exe, NuGet package, or .NET SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? To fix the issue, please install the latest version of .NET 6.0 or .NET Core 3.1 and NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version 4.9.5, 5.7.2, 5.9.2, 5.11.2, 6.0.2, 6.2.1). If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. You can get the version of NuGet.exe by running the‚ÄØ`nuget`‚ÄØcommand. You should see an output like the following: ``` NuGet Version: 6.0.0.280 usage: NuGet [args] [options] Type 'NuGet help ' for help on a specific command. To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://www.nuget.org/downloads ``` If you're using NuGet.exe 6.2.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.2.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.2.1/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 6.0.1 or lower, you should download and install 6.0.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.0.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.11.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.11.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.11.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.9.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.9.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.9.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.7.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.7.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.7.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.2.0 or lower, you should download and install 5.2.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.2.1/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 4.9.4 or lower, you should download and install 4.9.5 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v4.9.5/nuget.exe. You can list the versions you have installed by running the‚ÄØ`dotnet --info`‚ÄØcommand. You should see an output like the following: ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.300 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` If you're using .NET Core 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.6 or SDK 6.0.106 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.0) or SDK 6.0.301 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.2) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. If you're using .NET Core 3.1, you should download and install Runtime 3.1.26 or SDK 3.1.420 (for Visual Studio 2019 v16.9 or Visual Studio 2011 16.11 or Visual Studio 2022 17.0 or Visual Studio 2022 17.1) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/3.1 .NET 6.0 and .NET Core 3.1 updates are also available from Microsoft Update. To access this either type "Check for updates" in your Windows search, or open Settings, choose Update & Security and then click Check for Updates. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed‚ÄØself-contained applications‚ÄØtargeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 5 or .NET 6.0, please email details to‚ÄØ[secure@microsoft.com](secure@microsoft.com). Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at‚ÄØ[https://aka.ms/corebounty](https://aka.ms/corebounty). ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repo is located at‚ÄØ[https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client). The [Announcements repo](https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues) will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### External Links [CVE 2022-30184](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-30184) ### Revisions V1.0 (June 14, 2022): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2022-06-14_
